title: Censing Angels
description: A plaque originally decorating an altar cross; depicts angels censing something below, likely another panel showing Christ
subject: angels; censers
source: The Cloisters, The Metropolitan Museum of Art; https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/474263

title: Taymouth Ave Maria 1
description: The first image in a set of two bas-de-page illustrations from the Taymouth Hours depicting "The Monk who Only Knew the Ave Maria." Here, the monk learns the Ave Maria from Mary.
subject: Mary; Ave Maria; Prayer
source: The British Library Yates Thompson MS 13, fol. 161r; https://www.bl.uk/catalogues/illuminatedmanuscripts/record.asp?MSID=8148&CollID=58&NStart=13

title: Taymouth Ave Maria 2
description: The second image in the Taymouth Hours depicting "The Monk who Only Knew the Ave Maria." The monk has died. The other monks find a lily growing out of his mouth, signifying the monk's connection with Mary as well as the sweet scent of his prayers.
subject: Mary; Ave Maria; Prayer; Lily
source: The British Library Yates Thompson MS 13, fol. 161v; https://www.bl.uk/catalogues/illuminatedmanuscripts/record.asp?MSID=8148&CollID=58&NStart=13

title: Panther
description: An English bestiary image of the panther, a creature that draws animals to it with its sweet breath. The panther is allegorically interpreted as Christ.
subject: Panther
source: The British Library Harley MS 3244 fol. 37; https://www.bl.uk/catalogues/illuminatedmanuscripts/record.asp?MSID=8798&CollID=8&NStart=3244

title: Whale
description: An English bestiary image of the whale, a creature that draws fish to it with its sweet breath and then eats them. Sailors mistake it for an island and are drowned by it. The whale is allegorically interpreted as the Devil.
subject: Whale
source: The British Library Harley MS 4751 fol. 69r; https://www.bl.uk/collection-items/bestiary-with-extracts-from-giraldus-cambrensis-on-irish-birds

title: St. Louis (Louis IX) Chapel Windows
description:
An engraving of the original (now lost) windows of the St. Louis Chapel at St-Denis Basilica in Paris. St. Louis picks up the bones of dead Crusaders while others cover their noses at the stench of the bodies. In Bernard de
Montfaucon, Les Monumens De La Monarchie Franȯise, fig. 24 (Paris, 1730).
subject: St. Louis
source: Universitatsbibliothek Heidelberg, Bernard de Montfaucon, Les Monumens De La Monarchie Françoise, vol. 2 (Paris, 1730); https://digi.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/diglit/montfaucon1730bd2
identifier: Bernard de Montfaucon, Les Monumens De La Monarchie Françoise, vol. 2 (Paris, 1730)

title: St. Louis (Louis IX), Hours of Jeanne d'Evreaux
creator: Jean Pucelle
description: St. Louis collecting the bones of dead Crusaders while others are digusted by the stench.
subject: St. Louis
source: The Cloisters, The Metropolitan Museum of Art; The Hours of Jeanne d'Evreaux, fol. 159v; https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/470309

title: Marcantonio Raimondi after Raphael, Il Morbetto
creator: Marcantonio Raimondi
description: A copy of a work of Raphael depicting the Plague of Phrygia from the Aeneid; the people on the lower right side of the image turn away from the stench of the dead to prevent infection. A man holding his nose turns the face of a child away from his dead mother.
subject: Plague

title: Vesalius, Olfactory Organs 1
creator: Andreas Vesalius
description: Vesalius argues that the olfactory organs are in a different place than medieval scholarship had located them since the 12th c. This is a bottom view of the brain showing the elongated olfactory organs at the center top (marked F).
subject: olfactory organs; Vesalius
source: Universitatsbibliothek Basel; Vesalius, Andreas: Andreae Vesalii Bruxellensis, scholae medicorum Patavinae professoris, de Humani corporis fabrica Libri septem. Basileae: [ex officina Ioannis Oporini], [Anno salutis reparatae 1543]. Universitätsbibliothek Basel, AN I 15, https://doi.org/10.3931/e-rara-20094; bk. 4, ch. 1, fig. 9, pg. 318

title: Vesalius, Olfactory Organs 2
creator: Andreas Vesalius
description: A top view of a human brain with the front of the brain pulled back to reveal the olfactory organs. Vesalius locates the part of the brain that medieval scholars considered the olfactory organs at I. He locates the true olfactory organs at C and D.
subject: olfactory organs; Vesalius
source: Universitatsbibliothek Basel; Vesalius, Andreas: Andreae Vesalii Bruxellensis, scholae medicorum Patavinae professoris, de Humani corporis fabrica Libri septem. Basileae: [ex officina Ioannis Oporini], [Anno salutis reparatae 1543]. Universitätsbibliothek Basel, AN I 15, https://doi.org/10.3931/e-rara-20094; bk. 7, fig. 12, pg. 617.
